raw_text:
More power to the people says HP
 
 The digital revolution is focused on letting people tell and share their own stories, according to Carly Fiorina, chief of technology giant Hewlett Packard.
 
 The job of firms such as HP now, she said in a speech at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES), was to ensure digital and physical worlds fully converged. She said the goal for 2005 was to make people the centre of technology. CES showcases 50,000 new gadgets that will be hitting the shelves in 2005. The tech-fest, the largest of its kind in the world, runs from 6 to 9 January. "The digital revolution is about the democratisation of technology and the experiences it makes possible," she told delegates. "Revolution has always been about giving power to the people." She added: "The real story of the digital revolution is not just new products, but the millions of experiences made possible and stories that millions can tell." Part of giving people more control has been about the freeing up of content, such as images, video and music. Crucial to this has been the effort to make devices that speak to each other better so that content can be more easily transferred from one device, such as a digital camera, to others, such as portable media players. A lot of work still needs to be done, however, to sort out compatibility issues and standards within the technology industry so that gadgets just work seamlessly, she said.
 
 Ms Fiorina's talk also touted the way technology is being designed to focus on lifestyle, fashion and personalisation, something she sees as key to what people want.
 
 Special guest, singer Gwen Stefani, joined her on-stage to promote her own range of HP digital cameras which Ms Stefani has helped design and which are heavily influenced by Japanese youth culture. The digital cameras, which are due to go on sale in the US by the summer, are based on the HP 607 model. The emphasis on personalisation and lifestyle is a big theme at this year's CES, with tiny, wearable MP3 players at every turn and rainbow hues giving colour to everything. Ms Fiorina also announced that HP was working with Nokia to launch a visual radio service for mobiles, which would launch in Europe early this year. The service will let people listen to radio on their mobiles and download relevant content, like a track's ringtone, simultaneously. The service is designed to make mobile radio more interactive.
 
 Among the other new products she showcased was the Digital Media Hub, a big upgrade to HP's Digital Entertainment Centre. Coming out in the autumn in the US, the box is a networked, high-definition TV, cable set-top box, digital video recorder and DVD recorder. It has a removable hard drive cartridge, memory card slots, and Light Scribe labelling software which lets people design and print customised DVD labels and covers. It is designed to contain all a household's digital media, such as pre-recorded TV shows, pictures, videos and music so it can all be managed in one place. The hub reflects the increasing move to re-box the PC so that it can work as part of other key centres of entertainment. Research suggests that about 258 million images are saved and shared every day, equating to 94 billion a year. Eighty per cent of those remain on cameras. Media hubs are designed to encourage people to organise them on one box. Ms Fiorina was one of several keynote speakers, who also included Microsoft chief Bill Gates, to set out what major technology companies think people will be doing with technologies and gadgets in the next 12 months. In a separate announcement during the keynote speech, Ms Fiorina said that HP would be partnering MTV to replace this year's MTV Asia music award. MTV's Asia Aid will be held in Bangkok on 3 February, and is aimed at helping to raise money for the Asian tsunami disaster.
llama3.2:1b:
Here is a summary of the text in plain text:

Carly Fiorina, chief of HP technology, spoke at CES about the digital revolution and its focus on empowering people through technology.
She emphasized that tech firms like HP aim to converge the digital and physical worlds, making people the center of technology.

Fiorina discussed how companies are creating new products and services that allow people to control their content and experiences more easily, such as devices that can transfer data between different devices.

She also talked about the importance of personalization and lifestyle in technology design, including wearable MP3 players with customizable colors and HP's Digital Media Hub, a networked TV, cable set-top box, digital video recorder, and DVD recorder.
Fiorina announced partnerships with Nokia to launch a visual radio service for mobiles and highlighted the increasing move towards re-boxing PCs as part of other entertainment centers.

Key points include:

* The digital revolution aims to empower people through technology
* Companies like HP aim to make people the center of technology
* New products and services, such as wearable MP3 players and a networked TV, will be showcased at CES.
* HP is partnering with Nokia to launch a visual radio service for mobiles.
llama3.2:3b: HP emphasizes people-centric approach in digital revolution, focusing on convergence of physical and digital worlds, democratization of technology, and giving power to individuals; Carly Fiorina discusses importance of content freedom, device compatibility, lifestyle, fashion, and personalization; HP launches new products including Digital Media Hub and visual radio service.
gemma2:2b: HP believes the digital revolution empowers individuals to tell their own stories and share experiences through technology.
The company aims to achieve this by merging digital and physical worlds and making devices work seamlessly together.
They emphasize the importance of personalization, lifestyle integration, and interoperability in digital products.
HP highlights new initiatives like visual radio on mobile phones and a high-definition media hub for managing digital content.
They are also partnering with MTV to host MTV Asia Aid, raising funds for the Asian tsunami disaster relief efforts.
qwen2.5:0.5b: More power to the people says HP.
The company highlighted how it aims to focus on giving people more control over digital technologies and experiences.
They emphasized letting people share their stories through gadgets like cameras, and that this will make them the center of technology.

They also talked about digital lifestyle content, personalization, and the potential for smart devices, wearable media players, streaming services, digital media hubs, and TV sets with built-in digital media capabilities.
The company highlighted how it has partnered with companies to bring new products into the market, like HP's Digital Entertainment Centre that includes a digital video recorder.
qwen2.5:1.5b: HP CEO praises digital revolution; new products focus on lifestyle, personalization, and seamless technology integration.
Highlights include HP Digital Media Hub, featuring a networked TV set-top box with removable hard drive and memory card slots, designed to serve as a single hub for all household media.
Also showcased are specially designed HP cameras by singer Gwen Stefani aimed at leveraging Japanese youth culture influence.
qwen2.5:3b: More power to the people says HP.
In a speech at CES, Hewlett Packard’s chief Carly Fiorina emphasized making technology accessible and central to personal stories.
She highlighted efforts to make digital and physical worlds converge, focusing on user experiences like image sharing, video streaming, and music downloading.
Fiorina stressed that while new gadgets are important, the real revolution lies in enabling people to tell their own stories.
She also discussed HP's collaboration with Nokia for a mobile radio service and unveiled a media hub designed for easier management of digital media.
The tech industry is moving towards personalization and lifestyle design as key trends at CES, supported by products like wearable MP3 players and customizable DVDs.
Fiorina noted that 258 million images are saved daily on cameras but only 80% are organized digitally.
She announced a partnership with MTV to replace the Asia Music Awards due to the Asian tsunami disaster.
opencoder:1.5b: The digital revolution is centered around enabling people to experience their own ideas and stories, focused on democratizing technology and making it a sustainable platform.
The main focus has been on freeing up of content so that gadgets can function as intended, while also offering a wide variety of experiences for the end-users.
This talk focuses on the role of HP in this transformation, focusing not only on its products but also on its strategic plans to make technology more user-friendly and accessible.

Ms Stefani also announced that HP was working with Nokia to launch a visual radio service for mobiles, which will let people manage all their digital media, like pre-recorded TV shows, pictures, videos and music so it can all be managed in one place.
The service is designed to contain all a household's digital media, such as pre-recorded TV shows, pictures, videos and music so it can all be managed in one place.
Among the other new products she showcased was the Digital Media Hub, a big upgrade to HP's Digital Entertainment Centre.

deepseek-r1:1.5b: The digital revolution is centered around empowering individuals to create and share experiences through interconnected media.
At the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in 2005, Carly Fiorina highlighted that HP's role was to make this possible by ensuring that digital and physical worlds converged.
She emphasized democratizing technology and the experience it creates, aiming for a society where people are the center of technological innovation.
HP focused on making content transferable between devices, such as images from a digital camera to a portable media player.
This connectivity was crucial for transferring and sharing experiences.
They also worked on standardizing devices to ensure seamless communication within the tech industry, with efforts still needed to resolve compatibility issues.
HP's approach centered on personalization and lifestyle, using tiny MP3 players with rainbow hues of color and partnering with mobile radio services that enhanced interactivity.
Their Digital Media Hub was a networked system containing all household media, offering a centralized space for organizing and managing digital content.
MSD highlighted HP as part of a tech company with various leaders, including Bill Gates from Microsoft, discussing future trends.
The event also saw partnerships like Microsoft and MTV, which introduced the MTV Asia Music Award (MTV-A) to help raise funds during a tsunami disaster in 2011.
HP's work aimed to create a platform for personalizing experiences and organizing media within a connected world, leveraging advancements in personal computing and entertainment.

Her speech emphasized the importance of personalisation and life style in what people want, and HP has introduced innovative products such as the Digital Media Hub that can manage all their digital media.

Ms Fiorina also announced that the company was working with NokiA to launch a visual radio service for mobile phones, which would allow users to listen to radio on their mobiles simultaneously, and is designed to make mobile radio more interactive.

"Revolution has always been about giving power to the people."
She added: "The real story of the digital revolution is not just new products, but the millions of experiences made possible and stories that millions can tell."
Part of giving people more control has been about the freeing up of content, such as images, video and music.

Crucial to this has been the effort to make devices that speak to each other better so that content can be more easily transferred from one device, such as a digital camera, to others, such as portable media players.
A lot of work still needs to be done, however, to sort out compatibility issues and standards within the technology industry so that gadgets just work seamlessly, she said.
Ms Fiorina's talk also touted the way technology is being designed to focus on lifestyle, fashion and personalisation, something she sees as key to what people want.
phi:2.7b: Carly Fiorina, CEO of Hewlett Packard, spoke about the digital revolution's focus on giving people power through democratizing technology.
She highlighted how HP is working towards a seamless experience by making devices that can speak to each other and freeing up content such as images and music.
Ms. Fiorina also announced the launch of a visual radio service with Nokia for mobile phones, allowing users to listen to radio on their phones and download relevant content.
The Digital Media Hub, which will be released in the US this autumn, is a central hub that contains all digital media in one place, such as pre-recorded TV shows, pictures, videos, and music.
HP also announced its partnership with MTV to replace the Asia Aid music awards.

Major technology companies, including Microsoft's Bill Gates, presented on what they believe people will be doing with new technologies and gadgets in the next 12 months at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES).
orca-mini:3b: HP Chief Carly Fiorina believes that the digital revolution is about giving power to the people and making devices more personalised and lifestyle-focused.
She spoke about how technology should be designed to cater to people's needs and lifestyles, and how companies like hers are working towards this goal.
She also showcased new products such as the Digital Media Hub, which aims to contain all a household's digital media in one place, and the HP 607 camera, which is inspired by Japanese youth culture.
Fiorina was joined on stage by singer Gwen Stefani to promote her own range of HP cameras.
hermes3:3b: HP says digital revolution focuses on empowering people by letting them tell & share their own stories, making them centre of technology, according to Carly Fiorina.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Carly Fiorina, CEO of Hewlett Packard, emphasized the importance of the digital revolution focusing on letting people tell and share their own stories.
At the Consumer Electronics Show (CES), she highlighted HP's goal to make people the center of technology by 2005.
The democratization of technology and experiences was crucial; this involved giving more control through freeing up content and improved devices that speak to each other seamlessly.
Fiorina also mentioned lifestyle, fashion, and personalization as key aspects of design.
At CES, HP showcased products like digital cameras influenced by Japanese youth culture and a visual radio service for mobiles launching in Europe early 2006.
The company also introduced the Digital Media Hub, which will contain all a household's digital media in one place.
chatgpt-4o-latest: HP's CEO Carly Fiorina emphasized at CES that the digital revolution is about empowering people by enabling them to share their own stories.
She highlighted HP's goal of merging digital and physical worlds, making technology more user-centric.
Fiorina stressed the importance of seamless device compatibility to facilitate content sharing.
She also showcased HP's focus on lifestyle and personalization, featuring singer Gwen Stefani's HP-designed digital cameras inspired by Japanese youth culture.
HP announced a partnership with Nokia for a visual radio service and introduced the Digital Media Hub, a device integrating TV, DVR, and media storage.
Fiorina also revealed HP's collaboration with MTV for Asia Aid, a charity event supporting tsunami relief efforts.
stablelm2:1.6b: The digital revolution focuses on empowering people through storytelling, according to Hewlett Packard's Carly Fiorina.
Companies such as HP now aim to ensure digital and physical worlds are fully converged with the goal of making people the center of technology.
The main objective is to enable millions of experiences that people can tell and share.
Devices speak better so that content transfers seamlessly between gadgets.
Designing technology for lifestyle, fashion, and personalization is key to what people want.
HP collaborates with companies like Nokia to launch visual radio services for mobiles, which will launch in Europe early this year.
HP is also working on the Digital Media Hub, a networked high-definition TV set-top box that contains all household digital media.
Around one million images are saved and shared daily, representing 1 billion a year; eighty percent of those remain on cameras.
granite3.1-dense:2b: At the Consumer Electronics Show (CES) in January 2005, Carly Fiorina, CEO of Hewlett Packard, emphasized that the digital revolution prioritizes making people central to technology.
She stated that HP's mission was to merge digital and physical worlds, with 2005's goal being to place individuals at the forefront of technological advancements.
Fiorina highlighted the convergence of devices for seamless content transfer between media players like cameras and portable media players.
She acknowledged ongoing challenges in addressing industry compatibility issues and standards.

Fiorina also underscored technology's focus on personalization, lifestyle, and fashion, exemplified by singer Gwen Stefani's collaboration with HP to design digital cameras influenced by Japanese youth culture.
The cameras, due for release in the US by summer 2005, are based on the HP 607 model.
A visual radio service partnership between HP and Nokia, launching early in Europe, to provide interactive mobile radio experiences.

The Digital Media Hub, an upgrade to HP's Digital Entertainment Centre, featuring a networked, high-definition TV, cable set-top box, digital video recorder, DVD recorder, and removable hard drive cartridge for customizable DVD labels and covers.
This device aims to consolidate household digital media management.
Additionally, Fiorina announced HP's partnership with MTV to replace the 2005 Asia Aid music awards, using the event as an opportunity to raise funds for tsunami relief efforts in Asia.
